"Goldman Sachs analysts have expressed concerns that curing patients could be detrimental to the long-term profitability of biotech companies. They suggest that the potential for delivering "one shot cures" in gene therapy and other treatments could lead to a decline in recurring revenue, which is crucial for sustaining cash flow in the biotech industry. This concern is particularly evident in the case of Gilead Sciences, which has seen a significant drop in sales for its hepatitis C treatments since the peak of $12.5 billion in 2015, due to the exhaustion of the available pool of treatable patients. The analysts' report, titled "The Genome Revolution," highlights the challenges biotech companies face when transitioning from successful treatments to cures, which may not be sustainable in the long term." - CNBC  The average salary for an oncologist in 2025 is projected to be between $315,000 and $450,000 per year, depending on factors such as experience, location, and subspecialty. - Sermo

April 2024 right before my son's 1st birthday I found out I had to gue cancer. I was eating applesauce and Motrin for 3 months before I finally had my surgery in June 6th. I went from 205 lbs down to 150. Bottomed at 145lbs. My surgery required me to have 60% of my tongue removed. The entire left side of my tongue plus extra to be sure it's gone. 78 lymph nodes in my neck were removed but only 1 came back cancerous. A 2nd node came back positive of cancer a month later. 30 days of radiation to my mouth and neck plus 3 days of chemo. Most people get 60 units of whatever the med is for chemo. I was given 100 units because of my age being able to handle it. My wedding August 24th 2024 was the last day I ate food because of the moth sores. I just couldn't do it anymore. I had to take a viscous lidocaine that was swallowable and then I had 5 minutes to eat much as I could before the pain came back. I was able to eat again by Thanksgiving 2024 luckily. I had to use a feeding tube to eat between those times. I'd wake up in the mornings and my 3 year old daughter would ask if Daddy took his medicine and everytime I left the house she would ask if I'm going to the hospital again. Saddest time of my life. In order to rebuild my tongue the surgeon took a flap from my right wrist and then to cover that part they needed a skin graft from my thigh. My dad died when I was young, like 1st gradeish. I knew what it was like to not have my biological dad around and I couldn't do that to my kids. They are what kept me going honestly. My wife worked extra hours that she could so I was at home taking care of the kids while struggling to stay awake from being tired and struggling to hold them and make them happy. You can watch people go through cancer and sort of feel their pain but until you live in you will never know. Near the end of my treatments I was throwing up without notice sometimes and because my wife was at work I had no help with it. Being immune compromised from the chemo I couldn't help my wife go grocery shopping or take care of the cat we had gotten. My wife is a blessing and I appreciate her so much. To give you a picture of what it took coming out of surgery... I went from talking to not being able to speak any sounds at all. I couldn't even close my mouth because I was so swollen. I couldn't close my mouth for several days. I had to have a wet sponge apply water to my tongue to keep it moisturized. Waking up from surgery I had to keep my neck in the same position for 48 hours. I could only move my left arm and leg. My right leg was weak from the skin graft and my right arm had tubes coming out of it because of the wound vac l. I had tubes coming out of my neck from behind my ears to collect blood. I lost the tip of my tongue in the surgery which you use to speak. I had to teach my tongue to move to the left when I speak to pronounce certain sounds and still have to do it. I have to keep a water bottle with me at all times because I have permanent dry mouth. From the radiation. Sometimes my saliva glands work and sometimes they don't. I can't eat like I used to because it takes so long to chew. Most of the time my food has to be reheated in the microwave a couple times before I finish because it takes so long to eat. Going back to work after 6 months out I struggled but I did 6 days at least 9-10hours of physical labor so my wife could take a break. Cancer sucks a lot but I fought like hell. My cancer has a 40% chance to come back because not only is oral cancer one of the most aggressive cancers but cancer also has a mild, moderate or aggressive make up and mine was the most aggressive form of oral cancer. I was advanced stage 3 almost stage 4. My cancer was labeled T4AN1 I believe. The tumor in my tongue was in my tongue muscles arteries and veins meaning the seeds of it could go anywhere my blood went in my body.

It was about 13 years ago, all at once my mom was t-boned at a junction, three cracked ribs, broken hand, crushed foot, and if that wasn't enough they told her she was diabetic, and just to really pile on the shit she was diagnosed with breast cancer on top of everything.  But she wouldn't accept that it was the end. She went in for what she felt was the bare minimum she could get away with. Didn't want to poison herself with all the unhelpful treatments. She wanted to fight it with lifestyle and dietary changes. And it went into remission not long after. They said they could barely even detect it.  About six months ago, I don't know when exactly, it came back. With a vengeance. A wretched, insidious vengeance. Slowly sapping her of her strength until she couldn't even stand up or walk on her own. We had to lift her out of her chair, and she had to cling to us for stability to shuffle through the house.  This last Thursday evening she collapsed, she'd gone completely limp, trying to talk but couldn't, we had to call an ambulance. Couple hours after they took her away we got a text saying she was stable, responsive, and ticked off about being brought to a hospital because we know how much she doesn't like those places. Thought for sure she was in the clear so everyone was sent home. But Friday morning she passed away before any of us could get to the hospital. Never even got a chance to say goodbye or tell her how much we love her.  What we thought had just been a bit of liver damage leaking fluid turned out to be her liver, both her intestines, basically everything in her lower abdomen had been obliterated by the cancer leaving the doctors scratching their heads wondering how the hell she had not only lasted for so long but was still entirely herself (albeit perpetually exhausted) right up to her final moments.  She was a fighter. To her very last breath, she wouldn't give up.  What drives me up the wall is she had finally found a primary who was 100% uninterested in "pharmaceuticals" and was completely on board with her that lifestyle and diet were the key. A doctor who had no problem saying "God designed our bodies for healing ourselves, we just have to use what He gave us." If she could have found him all those years ago maybe it would have stayed gone for good.
Lost my grandfather, dad and brother to cancer. My aunt had breast cancer, but through a double mastectomy, it was eradicated. Another one of my brothers has cancer, and my mom has Stage 4... And a few have lung cancer because of smoking. I love them but angry at them at the same time, because it feels they're taking themselves away from their family over fucking cigarettes. I am not judging at all. I am extremely sad, knowing some of my losses were preventable. I also understand at one time smoking was considered "safe," but shocker...they lied. TO EVERYONE READING THIS...If you smoke, PLEASE QUIT. I KNOW that's much easier said than done. That's not lost on me. I don't want you to go through what I watched my brother endure and what my mom is enduring. PLEASE PLEASE PLEASE stop. If you haven't smoked, don't even think about just trying it once. I want NOT ONE OF you to suffer or suffer the loss from at least one form that can be preventable. I socially smoked if I went out; I smoked on occasion for about five years, then one day, it hit me what I was putting in my lungs. I was able to stop immediately, and I know smoking is one of the hardest habits to quit, but you do not deserve to suffer. I know some cancers aren't preventable, but at least for lung cancer, I beg you, please please stop hurting yourself and those who love you. My heart is broken and breaking, and there's not a damn thing I can do to bring my brother back or to reverse my mom's condition. Prostate killed my grandfather and is what my other brother has. Fortunately, if caught early enough, radioactive seeds can kill prostate cancer cells... But for anyone who smokes, you're too valuable to hurt yourself; I have seen what it does, and I can't express how much I don't want you to suffer. I don't care if I don't know you personally; you don't deserve what it will inevitably do to you. Please please please please quit. You can do it. I promise you can. Also, to lower prevalence of other cancers, keep your Cortisol levels in check. Cortisol is related to adrenaline and is released when you're under extreme, prolonged stress. It's highly correlated with increased cancers of all types. But, exercise, healthy hobbies, taking time for yourself and understanding you don't have to take as much on as society tells you, will help lower Cortisol. It's also related to obesity, heart disease and a lowered immune system in general...Cortisol. It's insidious and the real, hormonal physiological effect of being overly stressed. I'm not referring to everyday stress, or stress that we encounter from time to time; I am talking about elevated stress from which you don't see relief. But, increasing natural beta endorphins, norepinephrine, oxytocin and serotonin will fight cortisol and naturally keep you healthier.  I care about your health regardless if I know your name... If this helps one person, then that means everything to me and those who love you!!!!!!  While we can't control everything, my Master's thesis was the effects of Cortisol...and I can say with certainty that lowering stress via healthy activities will interfere with Cortisol's harmful effects. Obviously I can't say by how much or how everyone would respond, but I do know stress is not just an abstract term; its catalyst, Cortisol, is real, but it can also be minimized. You're worth it!

I was sure it was an appendicitis or a gall bladder issue. They took me in and did a P.E.T. scan. I went back to the room and waited for the results. When the radiologist walked in I said ok Doc which is appendix or gall bladder. He looked at me and paused, You have Large B Cell Lymphoma and it has progressed to a stage 4. Fear raced over me and an immediate feeling of defeat and doom. I swear I think I sucked all of the oxygen out of that er room. My wife bowed up and said in the name of Jesus He will not die but he will live. I have never seen her be that forcefully vocal about anything. He proceeded to show me the results of the scan showing two malignant growths. One the size of a football the other the size of a grapefruit. Lost my mom to cancer when I was just 13, which left me on the streets homeless caring for my 8 year old sister all alone at the time. Cancer is a brutal illness for sure, and in 2020 I had my own battle with it and thankfully I caught it early enough to completely win my battle. Have been 4 years cleared of it now and I am forever thankful for all the support I had from the people around me, without them and stuff like this song, those of us who fight such a brutal battle won't make it through the other side. I know 2 others who were youtubers who lost their battle in the same year I won mine, so I feel their families' pain and it's horrible to lose someone to cancer. So many people make jokes, and point and laugh at those who end up looking like aliens with no hair because of the treatments, but they have never felt that pain and I hope they never will, or they would never make such jokes. Same with any deadly illness....don't make jokes about it, it's not cool.   I've lost too many friends to cancer and I really do wish there was more I coulda done to help them through their fights too. The best thing I did for my mom was show her she was loved by a child who stood beside her no matter how hard things got for us. I showed her she could still find happiness in the end, and because of that she made it to her 40th birthday, lasting 2 years longer than they gave her when she was diagnosed. They said she'd have 8 months, I helped her achieve 3 years. And it would've been a won battle, but the doctors screwed up the radiation treatment and ended up burning her middle finger which rapidly spread cancer into her bones. From there it was all downhill and she just fell apart rapidly. I remember the last 3 days. She took me to school the first day, I wasn't picked up by her after school because she was unable to get out of bed....that's how rapidly it hit her. The next day she was put into Hospice, and the 3rd day, Thanksgiving Day, she was taken from me and it was the most devestating feeling a child could go through. I had to grow up very fast after that and work underaged illegally just to get some money to feed my sister so she would never feel pain. I ruined my health working so she could be ok. I eventually ended up in a Motocross contract (which I loved, being a girl doing that was a power statement to say the least lol), and that helped for awhile until I had a really bad wreck that screwed up my wrist and knee making it impossible to ride a motorcycle again. But it got us through that hard time, and we managed to buy this tiny home shed thing that was running on a generator. It got us through three years of hell and I finally was able to get a better job and get us a full apartment and from there things just got better. My little sister is happy with 3 kids and a caring husband now. I on the other hand am forced to live a life without another child due to cancer....it's such a shame that everything I have done and will always do to help others, I will never again have that happiness. (My daughter was shot in an alley after we were attacked on day and I lost her to that incident, then cancer ruined any other chances of having another child for me). Anyways, there is always hope on the other side of the hardest battles people will have to go through. If I could survive such a horrifying life in a city full of dangers and child predators, I know anyone else can too because I was not a strong person and it was hard but I somehow made it through. I hope this can at least help someone somewhere. Know you are not alone and you CAN make it through anything if YOU WILL IT!

I answered and put it on speaker. It was the doctor and I didn't expect anything to be said. She asked me if I had some time to go over my CT Scans. I said, "Sure. What is it?" Hopefully they are benign and we can just maybe do some treatments to remove the nodules or something. I am going to schedule you to see a pulmonologist." My wife was devastated, you could see it in her face. We just lost my grandmother to lung cancer in February 2020. Now, here we are, 3 years later, I am 36, soon to be 37 this December. And, I am looking at a potential death warrant. Not exactly how I saw my life going. But, there isn't anything I can do about it. I have two children. Child one is a 12 year old girl, beautiful, looks just like her mother and she is the sweetest little redheaded girl. Child two is a 2 year old boy. He is autistic, but he has a beautiful heart of gold. He smiles and laughs almost constantly. He is always so interested in exploring this world. Even if he can not speak yet, he still does what he can to communicate with the world around him. I love them both so much. I have gone into hyperdrive to find the most effective ways to make as much money as possible to make sure their lives are completely comfortable without me here. I couldn't imagine leaving them in this world without the means to make a decent life for themselves and have everything they need. Lord knows the government will do everything in their power to take everything from them with my passing. They will lay me to rest with a soldier's burial, but the honor stops there. They will rape my family given the chance. So, I just have to make sure i lay it all before their feet and plan it all before I go. From what I understand, I have about 5-10 years remaining. I better make those years count. Cause we all know the doctors aren't in the business of curing, but the business of making money. And, we all know how the VA is, the less of us there are, the less they have to spend and the more they can put in their pockets. Here's to my last 5-10 years on this planet. Hopefully, for my family's sake, I am successful in my endeavors. Fingers crossed!

It is shunned by the AMA and the medical 'experts' because they are told what to think and how to treat... Cut, Burn, and poison (surgery, radiation, and chemo) are big money makers for the industry. And it is a for-profit industry. A simple vitamin therapy would put them out of business because they chase the symptom and not the cause. There are many vitamin deficiency diseases like Scurvy (lack of Vitamin C), Rickets (lack of Calcium), Beriberi (lack of Thiamine), Pellagra (lack of Niacin), etc. B17 is found in several plants that we have destroyed through refining and bleaching. For example, B17 found in Sorghum molasses, and buckwheat, have been replaced with sugar and bleached white 'enriched' bread. The vitamin is found in the seeds of plants and in certain grasses. The highest concentration of B17 is found in the kernel within the pit of the apricot. But it is also in the seeds of prunes, apples, etc. A cancer cell is 'activated' when we lack this vitamin. Supplementing with B17 will stop the growth of cancer and neutralize it's destructive behavior. A cancer cell (aka trophoblast) also serves a purpose in the body. It is the trophoblast cell that eats away the wall of the uterus so the dividing embryo has a place to attach. Once the developing baby starts to have pancreatic function the cancerous process is halted. Cancer is cancer. It is just labeled differently because of the different microscopic appearance of tissues. It will manifest itself when the body is weak and deficient in nutrients. They are not different 'kinds' of cancer. It is the same destructive process found in different locations. We have these 'inactive' trophoblast cells throughout our body. The medical model for treating cancer is like taking an apple and cutting it in half and leaving it out on the counter. The exposed apple without it's protective 'skin' turns brown due to oxidation. The answer for the medical profession is to cut away the brown part. Well then what happens? ... It turns brown again doesn't it? ... The cause of the apple turning brown is that the removal of the protective skin allowed the 'meat' to be exposed. Cancer is no different. The controlling factor for the trophoblast cell to become 'active' is from a deficiency in B17.... The body's guard is down and cancer will show up in some location if not several. You will find that every search related to the medical profession will call this quackery. Of course they will. Because you cannot patent a vitamin. It is a natural cure. I get that you are upset, cancer is not a simple thing, though some pharmaceuticals may for sure put treatment behind a paywall, cancer is not something that can be all put in the same basket and cured with the same cure. There are different kinds of cancer. Plus, cancerous cells are cells from your body, that the body itself is not capable of recognizing that they have started replicating out of control, it is hard to target that, because they have no markers, so treatments will mainly target an area where there are cancerous cells, but they will also kill healthy cells, because there is no good way of distinguishing them at the moment, as far as i know, I am not a medical professional. Cancer is not sucks, it is one of the hardest things to cure, if detected early enough that it has not spread everywhere. But there is no they with a magical cure hiding it from us mere mortals. We humans like to think of ourselves as being in control of our lives, that somewhere in our added knowledge we know everything there is to know and we can cure everything there is attacking us, but the truth is, we don't know everything, we don't 100% know what every part of the body does, one day we may know, but life is quite complex, and as covid as proven, we have been lucky so far, all it takes is for an existing virus to mutate a bit and we get fucked. Super ignorant message in this song, I am going through chemo and I have read a lot about the history of chemotherapy/radiation and how we got to where we are now. People who think there is a "cure" for cancer are idiots, cancer is not ONE disease it is a giant category of many different diseases that manifest in different parts of the body with only the commonality of abnormal cells that continuously duplicate long after they should have stopped. The reason chemotherapy is so intense is because it targets mechanisms in the DNA and outer cell structures to kill cells in your body. Ideally, it will primarily affect the cells that are duplicating most rapidly - IE the cancer cells. It will also affect many other cells such as those in your mouth and stomach which is why many people get nausea. The ideal "cure" for cancer would have to be a form of chemotherapy that can target a very specific marker of ONLY the cancer cells so that it does not affect the rest of your body, but this is an extremely hard task which is why years of research have not brought us to that point. People underestimate how research, especially medical research, works in the first place. If you need to test how a treatment affects human beings you need a large population and to monitor effects for a long time. It is extremely ignorant to question why we don't have a cure when you probably can not name the mechanism of action of a single chemotherapy drug. As for radiation, once again it is another manner of killing cells. You HAVE to kill the cancer cells. All it takes is one cell for you to relapse. I am sorry for everyone else who had to go through chemo treatment, personally, I have acute lymphoblastic leukemia which I know is not a very lethal form of cancer for my age group. I feel very strongly for those who have terminal cancer and are not left with options. However, spreading misinformation and the idea that the "treatment is worse than the disease" is utterly ignorant and will not bring us any closer to helping anyone. Your cancer will 100% kill you without any treatment, and with treatment, many forms of cancer have a very real chance of being completely eliminated. As I said, all it takes is 1 cell for cancer to come back. Do not act like it is the doctor's fault or that they are hiding a cure or profiting off of this research. Cancer clinical trials are extremely expensive and long, and the doctors are totally dedicated to their work. They are not collecting money and kicking back. I absolutely hate this song, this man is the TRUE person trying to profit off of cancer by giving false messages and acting like he understands the struggle. He took a touchy issue and wrote a song to profit off of the emotionally vulnerable. Please for the love of God, if any of you out there are cancer patients or have someone close to you who is a cancer patient do not spread the ignorant message of this song that promotes an anti-medicine ideology.

From one cancer patient to another, I tell you this: *You never know how strong you are until being strong is your only choice* . You're stronger than you may think. There may have been days where you have cried, there may have been days where you've been asking yourself "How did I end up like this?" or "Why me?!", there may have been days where you're suffering so much you just want everything to end, but that's exactly what the cancer wants you to do, to give up, to stop fighting, to think that there's no hope. And in the inevitable case that there's no return and death is the only thing that awaits me, I'd rather die fighting than dying after giving up and putting my head down.  Medications are not the only treatment. Your friends, your family and any other people that show appreciation to you play a big role, hold onto them tightly, they could be even more effective than the treatment itself. Cry if you need to cry, yell if you need to yell, just don't let those negative emotions stack up, it will only worsen things.  To all of you, may God bless you.

3 years ago a young, bright, and beautiful woman died from a rare cancer in her spine and nose. I went to high school with her and she was such a joy and the brightest star I knew going through school. She loved everyone and was always smiling and friends with everyone. 4 years ago her bones started to just break, simply from banging into a table. after her back broke in 3 places just from going down some stairs they did all the tests and found her cancer.....but it was already in stage 3. they removed what they could and did treatments and she slowly did ok. wheelchair bound, bald and beautiful still. she would send everyone messages on Facebook, video messages mostly letting us know how she was doing but she never would show us how she looked. Sorry, but this is ignorant, I don't mean that in the generically offensive way, but in the, you legit don't know what you're talking about here, like most people. It's not your fault really, it's just its never really talked about or used to mess with people, so a little help...  1. Cancer is not "Cancer". It's not a disease in that you catch it, or hardwired into our genetics, but rather its the result of a glitch in a cell which triggers, ironically, the mechanism that controls when a cell reproduces and dies to go out of control essentially making the cell immortal. Its caused from living and cellular damage from natural processes just not being perfect, radiation damage, a cell being in a place or structure which causes the cell to glitch, among a few other things. So when you get "Cancer" it's actually getting 1 of hundreds of cataloged variations on the things that caused that glitch to occur in a given place. Think of it more like "The flu" which you know is not 1 disease but thousands.  2. The "Cure" for cancer. Now that you should understand a little of what cancer actually is you should understand why there is no "Cure" or rather there is, for many cancers there are cures. Some that are really stupidly simple like moving a cell into an alternate alignment with the other cells around it which causes a chain reaction that fixes all the cells that cell has caused to go cancerous. Others have 0 chance of curing because by the time it presents symptoms the only thing that could be done would be to cell by cell rip it out of very difficult places . Our technology is getting to the point where we can do that, but it's not a "medicinal" issue but an engineering issue which is hard to solve. There are lots of things in the works though, like funny enough Coronavirus has taught the medical community a few new tricks which could lead to far better treatment because it can more easily target a cancer cell with poison/radiation without accidentally hitting healthy cells. Also... think about how impossible you probably think immortality is to get. Cancer is essentially the key to immortality, or at least part of it, so if we were to "cure" it... all of them... we would likely also have the tech for immortality.  3. "We made our world carcinogenic". No. This is the part about bad journalists like to mess with people comes in. Every thing is technically carcinogenic because every action you take, every interaction that is had with the world, slightly damages and wears on your body. This wearing of the body causes the need for it to be fixed and in fixing there is an associated probability that the cell "mutates" and becomes cancerous. Considering this is the baseline, it becomes obvious that anything other than dying causes cancer, it's just a matter of how much cellular damage then each thing does that needs to be weighed to say how carcinogenic it is.  Anyways, know this is probably more an emotional song and understanding these things don't make for quite a good emotional hit, but, maybe this knowledge will help someone, after all one of the biggest indicators of survival is dealing with cancer knowledgeably and practically. So may this info will help save someone's life or stem the tide of anger of thinking "why all this research has come to nothing". It hasn't. It's just a long road which we humans aren't too familiar with lately.

There are a few cures for many different cancers and preventative measures one can take to prevent or greatly reduce likelihood of it developing. The issue with "cancer research" is that there is no money to be made in a cure and they have a vested interest in keeping people sick with cancer because of the money that is made. The biggest problem is that there are so many things in our everyday life that cause cancer. Limiting those greatly reduces cancer risk. Anything from cell phones emitting radiation, wifi, Bluetooth, cell towers (especially new 5g), vaccines, genetically modified (gmo) food, chemicals and pesticides sprayed on food, heavy metals in water and prescription drugs and plastics just to name a few.     The main way in prevention is keeping your body in an alkaline state and avoiding foods that cause body to become more acidic. Cancer needs an acidic environment to survive and reproduce. In an alkaline state cancer is unable to reproduce effectively. Use alkaline water for everything from drinking to cooking and every thing else. Baking soda can be added to water to raise alkalinity (1/4 teaspoon per 32oz of water) Meat, eggs, and dairy are the most common foods that cause acidity in the body. The other most common is any refined sugar (cane sugar, honey, fructose, high fructose syrup) and anything containing those like any sweets( candy, soda, cookies) just to name a few. Type in "alkaline food chart" on any search engine for a guide to this. Most are not aware of this but sugar actually feeds a fuels cancer so elimination of sugar in cancer patients is a MUST DO. I personally know people who have used baking soda to rid their body of cancer and are still cancer free. They take 1/8 to 1/4 teaspoon in 8 oz. of water 3 to 6 times a day. Baking soda changes p.h. levels to a more alkaline state. Another thing people have used to get rid of cancer is vitamin b17 mainly from apricot seeds. Turmeric with black pepper (for higher absorption) has worked in preventing and killing cancer cells. High dose vitamin c has also been known to kill cancer. There is an I.v. form of vit c that works much better than oral but vit c should be taken every day regardless of the form. Consuming foods high in antioxidants is VERY important. Every thing from turmeric with black pepper, berries like blueberries and acai, lemon and ginger, and vitamin c are just a few antioxidant rich foods.    Last but not least, cannabis and cannabis products have been known to kill cancer cells. T.h.c. is the main thing that does this but having other cannabinoids (c.b.d. or c.b.n.) along with t.h.c. can strengthen that. The goal of this project is to create a living human cell from its basic raw chemicals. 3 years ago on December 10th, 2017 at 7:53 AM, my grandmother lost her battle with cancer. She had lung cancer that had spread to multiple other organs. Some of my family believes shes known for a while because we found out she was hiding it from us in May that same year. The doctors said she would only live for 3 more months at the most. She lived for 7 months after that. The day before it happened, she chose to be home (which was and still is my house) for when it happened, because even she knew that she didn't have much longer to live. She went out with my aunt Ryan for her last smoke before telling me the last thing i will ever hear from her... "I love you all, I'm sorry for being such a burden." That night, we all stayed up waiting, none of us could sleep until very late. I fell asleep around 5AM on the floor out of pure exhaustion. I was woken up at about 7:55 and told that she had died just two minutes prior. I woke up my cousin who was sound asleep in my bed and told him what had happened. Being 17, I still didn't show any emotion until I saw her. I saw her laying in the brand new hospital bed that they had set up in her room to replace her bed. About 20 minutes after she was bagged up and rolled out of the house, my aunt Ryan and uncle Corey had told us about what had happened. My aunt Ryan caught herself falling asleep so she went to get Corey to trade shifts. By the time Corey walked in, she was gone. We believe she fought until no one was looking just so none of us had to witness it, but for me, seeing her lying down, not moving or breathing as she was doing prior to the incident, was enough for me to have a mental breakdown. About an hour later, i called my boss and told her that i wasnt going to be in because of what happened. she said it was ok and that i could take as much time as i needed (even though my job had a 3 day grieving policy which is basically 3 paid days off).

Thank you for making this video hun!  I am just one of the fighters you speak of.  I have been battling breast cancer for 2 and a half years now.  I have ZERO genetic markers for any type of cancer.  I had them check everything! My cancer is triple negative and the most aggressive type of breast cancer with a higher recurrence odds. I have gone through 27 rounds of chemo which had horrible side effects with my brain especially my memory (More on that in a minute). It also has destroyed my joints and I am in constant pain.  But I keep fighting!  I had 22 rounds of radiation which burned me so horribly that when my husband forced me to go to the hospital because he was so scared that the burns were getting infected, the nurses were horrified and one even cried when I showed her.  I also had to have surgery and they removed the surrounding tissue where the tumors were.  I say were, because by the time I was scheduled for surgery, the tumors were gone!  I had scans two weeks ago and the Drs. at the hospital said they found "Suspicious Tissue" where the cancer was.  My oncologist however said she's not worried and thinks it's just malformed tissue from the treatments and surgery.  She said and I quote "Those doctors are just not used to cancer being CURED!!" I'm praying she is right, but my appointment for further tests isn't until next month so I have to wait and stress over the what ifs.  In the meantime, I have, since being diagnosed with cancer started to follow my dream.  I have started an online business teaching students in the US and UK how to read tarot professionally.  I am getting ready to launch two new online courses that will be hopefully ready to launch on Nov. 5th! I have struggled with my own learning of tarot because of the damage to my memory that chemo did, but I thank god every day that he chose to test me in this way because of cancer and my memory issues, I created my own way of "Memorising" the meanings of the tarot cards and have taught a small group of people with astonishing results for them and that is what my courses teach.  My memory system and I will continue to fight to allow people to see that cancer even though it's a devastating and traumatic disease, it doesn't have to stop your life.  You can still live, love, grow, and help others along the way.  Keep spreading your message of hope, faith, and strength.  It is so truly needed by people like myself.
Love you Tom, keep the faith and stay the course. Keeping being you my dude.

Here's a long but hopefully educational comment:  Tl:dr: Developing new cancer treatments in like simultaneously finding a needle in a haystack while wondering a forest blind. You're looking for the gene mutation that caused the cancer without really knowing what the patients genome is supposed to look like, where the DNA got messed up at that changed a gene, or what combination of genes lead to the cancer. And keep in mind, the human genome is huge. An international team of scientists in labs all around the world were assigned what they called "small dna segments" for decoding but the human genome is so big that it still took about 30 years to complete the project.   So! Cancer treatment actually isn't an easy thing to go about and I would know because I am both a cancer patient and someone trying to go to pharmacy school to get into cancer treatment research.  Let's start with the general statement that there are many different types of cancer but cancer can be generally thought of as a cell that underwent an event that messed up a piece of DNA. Usually that piece of DNA is a gene that codes for a protein that are used in the cell signal to stop cell division.  Now you would think this would be something easy to study right? Sounds simple and today's technology is faster and better then ever before right? Well, you are very wrong. Sure, technology has advanced like crazy especially since the early 70's when scientists first started looking into genetics and how it relates to diseases, but advanced technology doesn't mean much if you can't figure out what you need it to look for. To know what to look for in the development of treatments for cancer, one must first know how a cell becomes cancerous. Here are a few ways a cell can become cancerous that I can remember off the top of my head: 1) There are mechanisms in your body that purposely change DNA to allow greater genetic variety that could lead to the development of a cancerous gene (RAG proteins are proteins in your body that do this and it literally allows the function of one half of your immune system). 2) Then there is the possibility of an error occuring during DNA scrambling during normal cell division.  3) There are also proteins that are supposed to copy your DNA exactly that accidently mess up by either using the wrong DNA base, adding a DNA base where there shouldn't be one, or deleting a DNA base. 4) There are proteins who's job is to cut up DNA to get rid of bad pieces that either don't work or work too well.  5) There are environmental factors like UV light damaging DNA, toxins that your own body produces and uses to try and keep you healthy that can destroy DNA, or chemicals that people ingest that damage DNA.   Remember, damaged or destroyed DNA can lead to cancer and any of the 3.something trillion cells in your body can become cancerous everyday by one of the ways I listed.  "But if DNA being damaged or messed up can cause cancer in any of my trillions of cells everyday, why isn't cancer more prevalent?" might be you next question. Well that leads into reason number two that cancer research for new treatments is a giant cluster.  Messed up DNA isn't always reflected in your genes. And even if a gene does get messed up, that's no guarantee that a disease will come about. The truth is there is still a lot about genes and genetics that we just don't know. Sure we've decoded a genome and sure we now have genetic testing. But the truth is, what we know about the genome and genetics is a drop of water compared to what we don't know. As a species we have only decoded one person's entire genome from a single cell. DNA varies from one cell to another because some cells are specialized and some cells have undergonen some of those DNA changing events I mentioned earlier (that are natural processes your cells just do). In fact, geneticist are still discovering what genes do and how the expression of different combinations of genes leads to diseases. Also, as a side note, any genetic testing you've seen in recent years only looks at a larger picture of the chromosomes rather then each DNA strand and it's sequence of bases. So genetics is a stupidly complicated science that we haven't even fully decoded or understand. Which means scientist need more time to properly study the genome and genetics in order to produce any sound medicine from it. A process we have begun in really well studied diseases like down syndrome or chronic myeloid leukemia but until all diseases are well studied there will be a lack in our ability to use genetics in medicine.  Which leads to the last reason development of new cancer treatments are stupidly complicated. Medicine or treatment development has always been and will always be a high risk business. The scientists and doctors who work in cancer treatment are literally dealing with someone's life and they have to be extremely cautious. This means most doctors will use a halfway effective treatment plan with a long history rather then a new treatment plan that only showed promising results one or two times. Which means more time is needed in order for treatments to be approved for use.  An example of this is the miracle drug for CML patients, Imatinib. Drug developers started testing Imatinib in 1996 as a treatment for chronic myeloid leukemia. It wasn't approved to be used as a treatment until 2001. It took five years of experiments and trails to get a drug approved for one of the most well studied leukemias in the world.   All three of these reasons make cancer treatment a complicated issue. And that degree of complication makes cancer treatment a field that uses a lot of time and resources. But with seemingly so little results, people begin to question the validity of the field just because they didn't get a nice pretty cure-all drug. But the truth is that cancer treatment development right now is more like when the lightbulb was first being invented. There were a lot of failures at first but each failure led the inventor closer to getting it right. Cancer research is the same. We don't have all the answers just yet but we're learning a lot as we go. Scientists just need more time.

Cancer is created during cell reproduction. Specifically during G2 checkpoints. An error is missed causing the cell to become cancerous. Usually our other healthy cells are really good at identifying and destroying the cancerous cell. However if it is missed it will spread. Whenever you get older your other cells can start to fall behind and fail at destroying the cancer, hence why people usually develop cancer at an older age. For the young people who get it naturally without smoking or any other cancer inducing activities are just extremely unlucky. Smoking can cause cancer because it kills the cells in your lungs causing more cellular reproduction and less thorough checkpoints. So please don't smoke. Just sharing what little information I have on cancer.

love the message, it's a sweet one.   but, let's talk about the music a sec, specifically the vocals.   The chorus is fine, and it is actually more than fine. it's pretty catchy. The verses where he raps though, its lacking a bit. (edit* no, it's lacking a LOT) the content of what he is saying is being overshadowed by the lack of any sort of punch. Most rap has some punches in it, this one is full of a bunch of feints. again, it's not the message that is lacking, that part is fine. it's the delivery of that message. that's what is weak in my opinion. that's what needs work.   throw some triplets in there.spice it up rhythmically.   practice your quarter-tone inflections and play around with quarter-tone melody lines.   Rap isnt just about being deep lyrically. there is music underneath it:  heavy emphasis on rhythm, secondary emphasis on pitch (quarter-tone pitch) and lastly lyrics. This priority is how you should build your rap verses. Right now, you have the message (lyrics) at the top of the priority list and that needs to change if you want to keep me interested.   Before you can infect someone's brain with an idea, you have to lure them in with style 1st. The message should be an afterthought.

Now I'm no doctor, so take everything I say with a grain of salt. However, from what I understand, cancer isn't just *cancer*. Even specific kinds of cancer aren't the same. Cancer being a mutation of a cell, it's different in everyone. The term cancer covers so many kinds of mutations, that once cannot simply make a "Cure" for it. Radiation kills cells. Not just cancer cells though, of course radiation has no bias. It kills all cells equally. It's hard to imagine any one Medicine being able to target thousands and thousands of different types of cell mutations, without it harming good cells too. After all, a medicine it's sentient. It doesn't make choices. Your body is what makes the choices. Just how people get the flu despite having a flu shot. Different mutations of the same thing. The common cold? Not so common in a sense. Thousands of different infections are all placed under the term "Common Cold." That's what makes cancer hard to cure.

I needed this man. I lost my Nan to cancer nearly 4 years ago. She had dizzy spells but insisted she was fine. Boxing day she fell and was taken to hospital, they did tests etc, and after 5 days in hospital, they told her she had two types of cancer. As soon as they told her, her mind snapped. She started talking to herself, and seeing things that weren't there. She stayed in hospital for another two weeks, her mind deteriorating every day, constantly saying she just wanted to go home. Finally they allowed her home, and arranged for carers to visit. Soon as she was home, she stopped seeing things and talking to herself, but she wasn't eating properly. After 11 days at home, she passed away. I was working that day and she kept asking for me. I went straight there after work, and just sat and held her hand. She had tears in her eyes and could barely speak. When I left, I knew she wouldn't last the night. A few hours later, at 2:40 am I had a call from my auntie (we took it in turns to stay the night with her) saying she had passed. I believe my Nan had held on to see me one last time.  She basically raised me, my parents split and I lived with my dad because I raced motocross, and my dad would make sure I raced. My Nan looked after me while dad was working. She would make my dinners and then make my sister and dad theirs. (I raced mx at a professional level, and had strict meal plans) my Nan came to every race, all over the UK. She would sleep in the motor home with us. One race was in winter in Scotland, it was snowing and freezing cold. I had to race as it was a round of the British championship, and my Nan insisted on coming along anyway, even though the motorhome would be freezing cold at night. She wanted to be there.  I miss my Nan so much, she was an amazing woman. She made it to 81 years old, and passed two weeks before her 82nd birthday.  We called her the old badger, because her hair went Gray in stripes, looking like a badgers fur.  Rip old badger, miss you loads.  Thank you Tom, this is such a beautiful song. Much love from the uk.

Two weeks ago I lost Ms. Beatrice, my Landseer Newfoundland dog to what we believe was cancer. It all happened to fast.  She was bleeding from her mouth and her nose.  We took her in for blood tests, and she had low platelets, which is usually a sign of cancer. She was scheduled for an xray to confirm in 2 more days.  On the night before that appointment she began crying in the night, and around 4am she was no longer breathing.  It happened so, so fast.  It turns out she had lost over 20 pounds in one month, but we didn't notice because she had just been groomed, and it just looked like lost fur.  She always looked skinny after being groomed because she's a long hair breed.  The very worse part is that she died at home.  In the past, all my pets got to the point where they couldn't walk anymore and we'd take them in to be put down.  Never dealt with a pet dying at home.  I had to help my dad carry her to his truck, and we took her to a family members farm to burry her next to my previous dog Buehler. I feel so bad we didn't notice anything sooner.  We had her for 8 great years (usual lifespan for large dogs is 8-10 years), and thought we had another good year left. I know this isn't quite the same as losing a person, or watching a loved one go through the treatments.  But it sucked so bad.

I lost my mom April 16th of this year, she passed away 4 days after her birthday from metastatic cancer. Her breast cancer came back and went undiagnosed for a year by her doctor who had told her it was just old age aches and pains, it had spread to her bones and she had to walk with a cane. Slowly over the next year she became bed ridden and depended on everyone. She couldn't get treatment because we couldn't afford any insurance that would cover it. We tried for almost 2 years to get medicaid to cover it and get her disability. She finally got it at the end of last year, far to late for any treatment by that point. The doctors said her body was covered in cancer. The hardest part was watching her try so hard, be so brave and strong one moment, then watching her break down crying and saying she didn't want to die, then to watch her rapidly decline to the point she needed morphine constantly to cope. She ended up getting gangrene in her feet and there was nothing they could do. They told us if they operated, she wouldn't make it through the surgery. I miss her everyday and still find it hard to not wake up with tons of emoji's and funny gifs telling me good morning and "I love you"s.  My mom would have loved this song. Anyone who is fighting cancer or knows someone who is, just stay strong and have hope. It's not over until it's over. I'm pretty sure that the Cytotoxic T cell will eventually lead to the cure. It's a cell that is produced as an immune response and directly targets and kills cancerous cells. It's currently being used in mice to reduce the negative side effects of chemotherapy with stunning results. Ramping up the production of these cells in a patient's body should drastically improve the survival rate and the risk of side effects in chemo. It would be interesting to see what would happen if we could harvest them in mass and inject them directly into the infected areas, but that would require human testing, which is a pain in the ASS to get approval for.  I've lost 1 friend and 2 relatives to cancer. It isn't fun to watch someone go from a happy-go-lucky individual to a human husk in just a few months. Instead of donating to research, it would probably be better to donate to the reward for whoever comes out with the cure.

Lost my father to cancer (myeloma) when I turned 18 and he was only 60. I'm 34 now... and sometimes I worry that half my life is over. He owned a home heating oil business but before that he worked for other heating oil companies, and at the time they used to do oil deliveries to homes without wearing gloves. The doctors suggested that maybe the oil seeped into his skin over the course of his life and caused the cancer. Myeloma is cancer of the blood cells.  But nobody really knows... I remember him sitting up in the hospital bed perfectly fine and asking me how I was doing in school (I wasn't doing well but I told him I was doing ok). He seemed full of life. Next time I saw him he was on life support and his body was completely covered in purple bruises. I hugged my mother and brother. I held his hand and couldn't stop crying... walked out of the room and a priest was there to pray for me.  They took my father off life support shortly after that. I can't avoid crying thinking back on it, even while I'm writing this. This song got me as well. When it was happening it was almost like I was in another dimension and this moment in my life completely changed everything. I never thought I'd lose my father... he was the light at family parties and always making everyone laugh. Every holiday after that you could feel the void he left in the air

Absolutely beautiful Tom. â¤
I've been trying to express this for a while now... A place where I can tell my story. I am 22 years old and on 10.19.2019 I was diagnosed  with stage IV Non-Hodgkins lymphoma that ended up spreading to my liver.  I only noticed it as a bump on my neck in the beginning stages of it, it ended up restricting my breathing quite a bit, ended up getting 3 tissue samples and plenty of cat-scans before they confirmed it to be cancer. (Before covid hit I would go in and sit with cancer children amd their families and just talk for hours getting them whatever they needed, cause I really cared for them  and I always told myself that I would take the burden of getting cancer if it meant a kid didn't.) After weeks of fighting with Medicare to be taken as a client because I could not afford it on my own  I was finally accepted. Fast-forward to September 6th  I  started my first treatment of chemotherapy. Chemotherapy is disgusting, pumping your body full of chemicals, killing  off the good portion of your body to dispose of the bad one, you're sitting in the chair, as you can slowly feel yourself get tired, then constant headaches involuntary muscle spasms, Severe nausea, sore throat, a constant feeling of vomiting (I did end up vomiting)  then eventually you're so fatigued after sitting in the chair for 8 hours (Can be longer or shorter based on chemotherapy, Mine was second from the most toxic) that you can barely move. I remember my mom sitting next to me, next to 10 other patients with this same expressionless face.  My chemo was supposed to be once a month for 6 treatments (six months,) but I was fucked over by the government cutting my insurance, making me miss 2 of my treatments which gave the cancer a chance to come back stronger and eventually spread. What was supposed to be 6 treatments turned into 11 due to their mistakes. I thought each treatment would get easier as I got more used to it, but the longer it continued the more hope I lost; out of everyone I knew, I was the most calm and collected so I couldn't afford to crack if that meant everyone else would break down as well.  I watched as my family was put into so much emotional and physical stress and I couldn't do anything except lye in bed for a year and watch.  I was put on many medications; 15 to be exact, just to try and reduce the severity of the side-effects of the chemo but to no avail. fast-forward to  10.19.2020, 11 treatments and a year later, I am now cancer-free with a almost fully functioning immune system. I have seen more people die during my time, half of them being children (7-15) for 50 people. Cancer is a disgusting disease and I wouldn't want to wish it on anyone. I would go through cancer as many times as needed if it meant everyone else wouldn't. I am still glad to be here, thank you so much Tom for bringing this topic into the light, I can not thank you enough.  #FUCKCANCER

there is no one cure for all cancers. because of what cancer is, damage to a certain part of the dna inside cells that causes them to grow uncontrollably, some things that work for one patient don't always work for other patients with the exact same type of cancer. cancer isn't a virus or a bacteria it is your cells multiplying uncontrollably creating masses of flesh inside you called tumors, if the tumors keep growing they strangle the other organs they are growing through and or around. the point of cancer treatments is to shrink tumors. either to the point of eradication or to where they are small enough so that they can be removed surgically. our immune systems actually are able to stop a lot of non aggressive types of cancers, but not all cancers are easily stoppable, the ones that make it past our immune systems are what we have spent a century and billions of dollars developing treatments and surgical procedures for.  even if there were a cure all for cancer that doesn't mean that cancer would be eradicated, millions of people would still get cancer and require the cure. as mentioned above it isn't a virus or bacteria that can be wiped out like small pox. as long as there is dna that can be damaged there will always be cancer.  my sincere condolences to all those who have lost loved ones to this illness.

The biggest thing to remember is that cancer causes the cells to divide so quickly and so often that it causes the genetic coding to degrade and cause tumors or other health complications that end up killing the patient, but if we could find a way to make these cells non-biologically immortal by either harvesting their telomerase or destroying their reproductive cell organs before they have a chance to divide out of control, then there is a good chance we could use that telomerase to give ourselves biological immortality and let the cancer age itself out, flip the script on it.

I'm just gonna leave this here. How PET/CTâ€™s Work: The PET/CT study involves having the patient fast before their scan and then get an injection of this radioactive sugar. They are then asked to sit in the waiting room for about an hour, giving time for the sugar to circulate around the body and be gobbled up by hungry cancer cells. Sugar is the #1 food cancer cells prefer to eat, so they load up on this 18-FDG like a kid in a candy store. Then the patient is brought back to the PET/CT scanner and are scanned from head to toe. Anywhere the sugar accumulates (i.e. cancerous tumors) shows up like a light bulb on the scan. https://integrativeoncology-essentials.com/2014/01/cancer-loves-sugar/

Tom, I love your content, but as a medical student I have to disagree with your comments about how there is a cure. Cancer is so hard to beat because it is not a singular disease. Everyone's cancer is unique to them, and is based on which mutations happened to their cells. It is impossible to create a single drug which can treat every type of mutation that exists. We can create therapies that target an individual's specific mutation, but it is still experimental becuase everyone's immune system reacts differently.  Cancer does not come about overnight. It is the accumulation of thousands of cell cycles, mutations, and DNA repairs until eventually one mutation pushes it over the edge and the cellular checkpoints can't stop growth anymore. It is always a race to the finish where doctors are late to the starting line. The rest of your song and video were powerful statements, and I thank you for them. Please understand that us in the medical community are doing whatever we can to make cancer disappear forever, but it is a near impossible task. Thanks for what you do Tom. Keep on making great music!

The amount of money used in research for a cure and its results have to do with the complexity of the many different types of cancers.  The pharmaceuticals that make it to market have to cover the expenses of each of the compounds that fail. For everyone that makes it through phase 1, 2, 3A, 3b, and do not get pulled during four, are several hundred. Once the drug has made it through the process the limited life of the patent is another major factor as to why the cost is so high. And finally, with everything we have developed we are approaching the flat of the curve, It is the law of diminishing returns. Ok imma just say I can't stand the myth of "cancer has a cure they just wont give it"  Cancer is a category of disease not just one thing. Every type of cancer is completely different and the idea that people who have dedicated their lives to curing various forms of it are suddenly bought off to withhold the cure is a conspiracy theory up there with the antivax loons.   Seriously, please stop perpetuating this idea that cancer has a cure. That is like saying all broken bones just require an arm cast - there are 206 bones in our body and the idea that we can fix them all with an arm cast is lunacy.  There are well over 100 types of cancer and although they are all in the same category of ailments the idea that we have a cure for all of them is insane. We do have a cure for some - that is why some forms of cancer have a massively low prognosis and others have an overwhelmingly high prognosis.  So yeah, love most of your music tom but you fell for the ideocracy of blanket statements in this one.

Hi,   Cancer is a very difficult topic to talk about, especially in terms of "cures". Yes, heavy investment is made, and tons of research goes into it. Though, it's really crucial to understand that cancer isn't just one sickness, it's thousands of sicknesses. There's a large number of different TYPES of cancers, and to find the CURE to all of them, is extremely hard, if not impossible.   Alongside the large number of different types of cancer, it's also very important to understand the large numbers of causation factors that led to the cancer, as well as previous individual history and sicknesses of comorbidity in the patient. All of these variables play a role in creating a "cure", which unfortunately is very complex and in order to study all of these variables, a ton of more research, has to be done.    In addition, regardless of contrary belief, a lot of scientists and researchers that dedicate their lives to cancer research are often affected with, or are affiliated with someone affected by cancer. They would never "hold back" a cure, for any sort of profit.  I can assure you that.   That aside, I'd like to put emphasis on eating a clean diet (unprocessed foods, balanced meals, high in antioxidants), participating in consistent exercise and healthy sleep habits, as well as various forms of meditation to ease the stress in our lives. Although this can't cure cancer, it will for sure reduce your risk of being sick with it.   Would love some more positive and productive discussion, feel free to reply!

Spring 2019 my dad got diagnosed with a sublingual tumor. Between 30yrs of smoking and major exposure to agent orange in Vietnam he was at high risk anyway. With a sublingual it is consider stage 4, even if it is caught early because it is inoperable. So they started him on chemo and radiation. He took the chemo like a champ. Used thc lemon drop candies to help with the nausea and was doing great. The radiation though. It shut down his salivary glands, irritated the lining of his throat. He was down to a cup of beef broth a day and some water. He went from 230 to 160 in a few months. His body consumed his muscles for protein to keep going. He could barely stand. He ended up having to go into a convalescent center, and the first 2 weeks there he was totally despondent. He required a feeding tube. I thank God for our priest. Father Joseph came ever day, talked with dad, gave him confession and communion, gave him unction, prayed with and for him. That started the process of lifting him up and helped begin the healing dad needed. He is now cancer free. But he will tell you that the cure came closer to killing him than the disease.  He never did finish his radiation treatments.

The problem with cancer is that year after year our natural immune system is bombarded with crap ranging from the things we consume to the things we put on our body. I made it through cancer treatment and I've been in remission for 9 years now.  When I finished treatment I asked my oncologist what is the best case scenario that I have?  His response was 5 years, but the cancer will come back, it's just a question where and how aggressive will it be?  Well at the five year mark my intestines completely ruptured and I went in to the hospital where I received 5 surgeries and was put into a drug induced coma in order to heal.  So I don't digest food very well but I count each day that I'm here as a gift from God who I believe is the main reason I'm still on this planet with y'all.  When my doctor told me five years I laughed in his face and I said well we'll see about that.  My best advice to anyone going through this is keep a positive attitude it really makes a huge difference.  It's hard as hell to do but I believe that positive thinking and fighting with all my heart in addition to God's help is why I'm still here.  Lose the negativity in your lives you don't need it and you don't deserve it.  My sister passed away at the age of 50 from cancer, my grandma in her 70's, my cousin in her 40's.  Also my oncologist gave me some of the best advice I've ever received during my radiation (30 straight days and 14 points being radiated) and chemo (2 rounds because it spread to my lungs during treatment) he told me make big plans right now while you're in treatment to do one of the biggest items on your bucket list.  So while I was in this treatment I planned a 2 week vacation to England and thanks to that little Aflac duck the entire cost was covered.  I went and oh I had a great time it was everything I thought it would be.  After getting out of the coma I went to Ireland for 2 weeks.  Make sure you take care of not only your physical self but also your inner self, it can be a difference between life and death.  Much love to you Tom for making this song, it truly touched my soul.

Brother died brain/spinal cancer.   Nephew died osteosarcoma.  Uncle stomach cancer--died.  You can beat cancer. My friend beat colon cancer.  But...if I get cancer, I will not do chemo.  It's a horror show.  Most of the cancers in my family have a low survival rate even with treatment. Because of the types of cancer we get, the chemo our family gets is harsh. Watching people I love go through cancer, chemo, hospice---has solidified my belief that people should have the right to choose death at a certain point.
